text: hi everyone Anthony Fantana here
intranets busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review of the new Steven
Wilson LPD Raven who refused to sing
Steven Wilson is a modern progressive
rock figurehead multi-instrumentalist
producer singer songwriter frontman of
the infamous porcupine tree and over the
years responsible for penning some of
what people consider to be modern
progressive rock classics mostly in the
late to mid 90s and early 2000s since
and I personally know a lot of people
who who hold porcupine tree and Steven
Wilson in very high regard very high
artistic regard which is why I've always
found it to kind of be a personal
tragedy of mine that I've never really
enjoyed his music no matter how much I
listen to it no matter how much I
revisit it and the thing is it's not
that I don't appreciate the genres that
he typically toys with I love
progressive rock I love jazz rock I love
the sound of a group of very talented
proficient musicians pushing each
other's limits performance wise that's
why I listen to Frank Zappa as well as
soft Machine and Mahavishnu Orchestra
and specifically artists that mr. Wilson
takes a ton of influence from like Pink
Floyd as well as a little bit of rush
some Jethro Tull and King Crimson as
well ranks are very high in the league
of influences Steven Wilson likes to
wear on his sleeve he takes a ton of
cues from these artists he essentially
with these artists does his progressive
rock homework
he's memorizing he's cramming he is
mastering the art of regurgitating the
musical ideas that these artists
perfected over their careers and taking
influence from the artists that move you
emotionally as a musician is something
that pretty much everybody does to an
extent but doing his homework is really
all I personally feel Steven Wilson does
especially on his
most recent solo efforts grace for
drowning and the Raven who refused to
sing Steven Wilson seems to have made a
career out of just being a student of
prog and that's it
none of his music to me personally
showcases the turbulent tides of real
life or personal experience pretty much
everything Steven Wilson has put out on
his most recent stuff to me is is just a
product of studying just very close
study of the art of old-school
progressive rock and the music actually
suffers because of it even though Steven
Wilson is really great at creating this
music to an extent it's not like
somebody who's actually familiar with
this era of music would mistake this new
album for an authentically vintage piece
of progressive rock the sounds
throughout this LP in my opinion are
actually really flat and kind of
unimaginative there's not much in the
way of interesting production on this LP
the drums sound really flat really
plastic they don't have a lot of body to
them they feel as if they were recorded
on a shoestring budget in a home studio
and other elements in this LP like the
faux mellotron sounds and the very
pristine piano chords that sound like
they're coming out of a synthesizer it's
kind of like that fake cringe-worthy
kind of piano sound as well as the very
pristine shimmering guitars it all just
to me says knock off knock off knock off
not only do the sound say that but
compositionally this album says that to
me as well the bass lines as well as the
drumbeats and fills are incredibly
incredibly textbook on this LP and the
vocals in my opinion consistently lack
passion Steven Wilson has never really
been one of my favourite rock vocalists
and it's because his voice kind of hangs
in this very high range but isn't
particularly a motive or
attention-grabbing in terms of
inflection or just putting a powerful
voice forward for the most part it feels
like the vocals are there because they
should be there according to the
progressive rock blueprint that Wilson
is working from whereas I feel he has
the chops to make this an instrumental
album if he wanted to or at least employ
a vocalist who is better at singing than
he is which with all of his musical
connections I'm sure
could have done you know honestly when
it comes to emulating Stephen Wilson has
a gift I'm not surprised he has fans
he's really great at emulating he can
play he can arrange according to these
formulas that he has studied and
memorized so well audibly aside from
maybe some nitpicking that I have with
some of the sounds not being lush enough
or being interesting enough there's
nothing technically wrong there's just a
severe lack of adventure and and
Soundcraft on this record that just
hangs over every song in a really
annoying way like the track watchmaker
which actually was one of my favorite
songs on here a very pretty acoustic
ballad opens this song up but it just
kind of feels like vocals by greg lake
with lyrics by peterson filled with some
acoustic guitar peji Austrade out of the
robert fripp playbook and then a flute
comes in which makes the song feel even
more formulaic
and really takes me out of the sweet
tender moment that mr. Wilson is trying
to make this song become I like the
lyrics on this track quite a bit Stephen
is telling a beautiful story that feels
very aged archaic kind of romantic but
the years of ice that have kind of built
up over my heart when it comes to
listening to stuff Stephen Wilson has
made because of just the lack of
surprises that comes with his music he
syncopated drum hits and then the bass
riffs on the opening track here right at
the start of it which feels a little
like rush inspired in a way maybe the
bass is kind of repetitive not really
altering as much as I would have liked
it but at least the song hits a good
groove and starts the album off at a
modest pace and the song drive home the
way the track starts off with these
piano chords it's very atmospheric and
these guitar solos just come in whaling
soaring over all of this rock
instrumentation it's really kind of
floyd esque then a King Crimson desk
acoustic guitar interlude comes in
smattered with a little bit of horns
it's very beautiful it's very detailed
but I feel like I'm taken out of the
moment right away because this acoustic
guitar flies in that feels like it's
arriving on a train schedule or
something like that again a great idea a
great idea that I feel has
tested and proven to be great on other
records for me personally it's it's hard
to enjoy this LP because I feel like I
catch Stephen Wilson with his hand in
the cookie jar just too many times I
would say the most modern thing about
this LP that isn't so distracting with
all these prog rock stereotypes is the
title track which is actually a very
pretty piano ballad
I wish the sounds were more interesting
like on many other tracks on here but
Stephen Wilson's voice actually sounds
pretty great on this song there's some
symphonic instrumentation coming in as
the song progresses it's a nice point on
the album that actually moved me in a
sense emotionally and though there are
some good ideas on this LP like this and
Stephen Wilson like I said is really
great at recreating those classic and
fantastic prog sounds there are some
moments on here that I don't feel like a
prog for father would have done or just
maybe would have not done as chisa lee
as Stephen Wilson has like the dududu
ascending vocals on the track watchmaker
toward the end of the song if you're
into prog rock and you really just want
to hear all the great albums that you've
loved over the years rehashed into a new
LP and just all the pieces you're
already familiar with just placed in a
different order in a different
succession then raven may just entertain
you unfortunately I'm not looking for
that really so like I said again this
album left me cold so I'm pretty much
feeling as the strong forty with like
five on this thing certainly it's not
terrible it's not horrible like I said
it's not like this album is offensive to
the ears from a technical standpoint but
from a point of emotion and inspiration
there's really not much of anything here
for me really so that's it if you've
given this LP listen what did you think
of it did you love it did you hate it
why what do you think I should review
next Stephen Wilson the Raven who
refused to sing Anthony Pham tanno
forever
you
you
[Music]
